Muller-Thurgau, a hybrid grape that the eminent British critic Hugh Johnson wants banned from top vineyards in Germany because of its wimpy wines there, has found a new identity, respect and pizazz in Oregon.
Last year, 15 producers turned out 25,147 cases, up from 20,042 in 1998.

Chateau Benoit in the Willamette Valley so prizes this white hybrid, which is partly riesling and partly Chasselas (a major Swiss grape), that it makes 7,500 cases a year, compared with 1,000 of chardonnay, which can be a sure-fire profit maker.
Benoit's lovely, near-dry, addictive '98 Muller-Thurgau is tastier and has more panache than 85 percent of the standard-issue chardonnays I encounter. And it's much more food friendly.

''Heat needs sweet,'' Peter Poster, Benoit's vice president, told the Wine Business Monthly, a California publication. ''When you are having hot food, the sweetness coats the palate and takes the edge off. Muller-Thurgau goes very well with Caribbean, Tex-Mex, Thai and Sichuan cooking.''

It's hard to decide what's most appealing in Benoit's charmer: its floral-pineapple-honey aroma; intricate, seamless, fruit-salad flavor; kiwi-like piquancy and grapefruity acidity, enlivened by a spritz (like J. J. Prum's memorable Mosel kabinett rieslings in Germany), which combine to create a cavernous appetite; or its 10-minute-long aftertaste.

The Muller-Thurgau costs $7 in Arlington Wine and Liquor, 718 Dutchess Turnpike (Arlington Square shopping center), Pougkeepsie. It is $8 at both Suburban Wine, 379 Downing Drive, Yorktown Heights, and Viscount, 1173 Route 9, Wappingers Falls.
At this price-quality ratio, it's worth buying at least half a case. (The distributor is C. Daniele, in Manhattan.)
The good news, said Scott Huffman, the winemaker, is that Chateau Benoit's '99 Muller-Thurgau, which may reach Westchester in December, is even juicier than the '98's. He's right.
